title: Zumthor's LACMA wing is 'bold and compromised in nearly equal measure,' says Christopher Hawthorne
author: Niall Patrick Walsh
excerpt: Architecture critic Christopher Hawthorne has published a review of the Peter Zumthor-designed David Geffen Galleries at LACMA. Fifteen years and $835 million in the making, the museum will open for a three-day preview beginning June 26th, with a full debut anticipated in April 2026. Related...
text: anchor Image credit: Museum Associates/LACMA It aspires to be a transporting, soup-to-nuts Zumthor ocean liner, with every detail designed by a single hand, but keeps springing leaks. At the same time, my sense is that Angelenos, thanks in large part to the design’s curious and openhearted attitude toward the city around it, will quickly embrace the new wing. — Christopher Hawthorne, Punch List Architecture critic Christopher Hawthorne has published a review of the Peter Zumthor-designed David Geffen Galleries at LACMA. Fifteen years and $835 million in the making, the museum will open for a three-day preview beginning June 26th, with a full debut anticipated in April 2026. Related on Archinect: Peter Zumthor details LACMA’s design inspiration in new interview. Image credit: Paul Petrunia/ArchinectIn the review, Hawthorne characterizes the project as a hamstrung Gesamtkunstwerk (German for 'total work of art'). While praising the building’s urban presence, openness to the city, and improved conditions for viewing art, Hawthorne also notes a loss of Zumthor’s signature detailing due to value engineering and budget cuts. "All in all—after all this time, money, and Sturm und Drang—Los Angeles is easily the better for having it," Hawthorne concludes. "It has been a punishing road for [LACMA director] Govan and Zumthor to get here. But the completed building, for all its faults, is an encouraging sign that Los Angeles is still capable of architectural risk-taking at key sites and the biggest scale."

• anchor

    Image credit: Museum Associates/LACMA

    It aspires to be a transporting, soup-to-nuts Zumthor ocean liner, with every detail designed by a single hand, but keeps springing leaks. At the same time, my sense is that Angelenos, thanks in large part to the design’s curious and openhearted attitude toward the city around it, will quickly embrace the new wing. — Christopher Hawthorne, Punch List

    Architecture critic Christopher Hawthorne has published a review of the Peter Zumthor-designed David Geffen Galleries at LACMA. Fifteen years and $835 million in the making, the museum will open for a three-day preview beginning June 26th, with a full debut anticipated in April 2026.

    In the review, Hawthorne characterizes the project as a hamstrung Gesamtkunstwerk (German for 'total work of art'). While praising the building’s urban presence, openness to the city, and improved conditions for viewing art, Hawthorne also notes a loss of Zumthor’s signature detailing due to value engineering and budget cuts.

    "All in all—after all this time, money, and Sturm und Drang—Los Angeles is easily the better for having it," Hawthorne concludes. "It has been a punishing road for [LACMA director] Govan and Zumthor to get here. But the completed building, for all its faults, is an encouraging sign that Los Angeles is still capable of architectural risk-taking at key sites and the biggest scale."
